answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
In most areas, but not all, phone and cell companies can and are required to provide First Responders, which includes most emergency and EOC staff, priority access for their calls.  Each First Responder is given a card with a dial in number and ID code that will clear the call through the switching gear if the gear and lines are operating.  This takes a little time to set up, but may still be able to get some lines right away.  
There is of course radios.  
I would recommend a few satellite phones for if all else fails.  You can lease these from many different cell providers on a monthly basis.  (if a declared emergency, if they won't rent them to you, you can probably commander them with an obligation to pay later.) This would allow you to stay in communications with regional, state and local authorities regardless of what happens to the land and cell lines or if a radio relay antenna goes down.

author: Alex Brown
text:
As we have learned from experience, cell phone networks are unreliable sources of information sharing during emergency events. Those communities in the path of Hurricane Irene may want to avail themselves of FEMA's social media resources, which can be used to receive critical updates.
FEMA mobile website: http://m.fema.gov/
FEMA on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/FEMA
FEMA on Twitter: http://twitter.com/#!/fema
You do not need to have a Facebook or Twitter account to view the information on these pages.
title: Hurricane Irene: FEMA Social Media Resources
